repnme.cdata!:
Nigeria - Southern Borno Agricultural
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Southern Borno
            Agricultural Development Project for Nigeria were as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory, project sustainability
            was likely, Bank performance was highly satisfactory, and
            Borrower performance was also a highly satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included:  to ensure compliance with
            provisions of the loan and project agreements on project
            implementation, authorizing the federal ministry of finance
            to permit the central bank of Nigeria to deduct counterpart
            funds at revenue source should be a major condition of loan
            effectiveness. Provision of rural infrastructure can enhance
            the rate of adoption of agricultural technologies and
            agricultural production, and the design and location of
            these facilities should be done in consultation with the
            farmers. The supply of farm inputs is best left to the
            private sector. Seed contract out growers with proper
            assistance can become independent and self-reliant
            suppliers. Also, farmers can independently source credit
            from financial institutions, but need initial assistance
            with loan applications and references. The problem of poorly
            performing monitoring and evaluation units is a generic one
            for many projects and the Bank needs to seriously review its
            approach in this area, with the aim of improving the situation.

repnme.cdata!:
Nigeria - Southern Borno Agricultural
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Southern State Agricultural
            Development Project will support the Borno State Government
            in providing improved services to the southern third of the
            state. It would aim to improve the supply of agricultural
            inputs, strengthen the extension service and develop small
            scale irrigation. Local communities would have access tracks
            upgraded, enabling them to be passable for a greater portion
            of the year. Some 135km of new tracks would be constructed
            to open up areas with irrigation potential. Rural
            communities would be provided with materials and skilled
            artisans to line hand dug wells. Project management would
            assist with the development of a more coherent long term
            organization for state agricultural services during the
            course of the project.
